Patch Set 5: > (1 comment) I think there are still problems 。 First from your url have one phrase：The list of type-specific methods automatically used by
assertEqual() are summarized in the following table. Note
that it’s usually not necessary to invoke these methods directly. Second if two different parameters, is there will be the exception, can't pass the test. So there is no what you say, reviewer look not to understand these two parameters type of problem. Third assertEqual() in testools is able to handle dict, list, set and so on. So we just call assertEqual() to make the unit tests simpler. What do you think?

Patch Set 5:

Hi Cyril, Kairat, 

I think this patch does have a point here, IMHO.

For example, as you can see in test_domain.TestImage.test_extra_properties, we are using assertEqual() to compare two dicts.

    def test_extra_properties(self):
        self.image.extra_properties = {'foo': 'bar'}
        self.assertEqual({'foo': 'bar'}, self.image.extra_properties)

And there are lots of similar examples in unit tests.

IMHO, this non-unification will confuse reviewers and developers if they don't know clearly what's the difference between assertEqual() and assertDictEqual().

assertDictEqual() is defined in unittest2, and use != to do the comparation. 

        def assertDictEqual(self, d1, d2, msg=None):
            self.assertIsInstance(d1, dict, 'First argument is not a dictionary')
            self.assertIsInstance(d2, dict, 'Second argument is not a dictionary')
    
            if d1 != d2:
                ......

The assertEqual() in unittest2 will be redirected to assertDictEqual() if the two params are dicts.

But most of the unit tests use testtools.TestCase which is based on unittest2 to do the test. assertEqual() defined in testtools is a little different, but it is also using != to do the comparation.

        def assertEqual(self, expected, observed, message=''):
            matcher = _FlippedEquals(expected)
            self.assertThat(observed, matcher, message)
    
    and:
    
        class Equals(_BinaryComparison):
            comparator = operator.eq
            mismatch_string = '!='

So actually they are the same. 


Furthermore, I think neither developer nor review should worry about the type of the params. != is overloaded in python classes like List and Dict. If we pass the wrong type object to assertEqual(), an exception will be raised and the test won't pass. 


And also, in the unittest2 doc, "Note that it’s usually not necessary to invoke these methods directly." has told us that assertEqual() will handle type issues for us.


So I suggest to avoid the usage of assertDictEqual() and all assertXXXEqual() from unittest2 in code. And just call assertEqual() to compare results. It will make unit test development more simpler.

Thanks. :)
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

Hi,
unfortunately, I still do not understand what does this unification bring to the project. assertListEqual is pretty good and clear here, you can use assertEqual as alternative but it is up to test developer what tool to use. I hope it doesn't seem bikeshedding from my side here but I tend to approve changes if they bring real value to the project. So I'll remove my -1 on the patch and let the other folks agree or disagree=).

Thank you for your review.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I agree with Kairat on this one.

These changes weaken the current tests.  The assertEqual() only uses the underlying assertListEqual() if *both* the parameters are lists, whereas assertListEqual() will immediately fail if one of the parameters is not a list.

I don't know whether the assertEqual(), assertListEqual() difference matters for these particular tests or not ... but I don't see an argument to that effect in the commit message either.

I know this seems like bikeshedding, but we are working on an opensource project where contributors come and go.  The tests in question were written a long time ago by people probably not on the project anymore.  I don't like the idea of weakening tests based on purely syntactic grounds.  The semantics of assertEqual() and assertListEqual() are *not* identical.

Please see this doc for more information: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/contributing/minor-code-changes.html#tests

(It explicitly states the requirement that an argument for the specific change must be given before this kind of patch will be accepted.)
